prefixDef.p: Private URIs using the teiCorpusHeader prefix are pointers to any element in the SHAWI teiCorpus document.
Private URIs using the share prefix are pointers to audio file residing on the SHAWI network share.
Private URIs using the geo prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a place element in VICAV Geodata list.
Private URIs using the zotid prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a biblStruct element in the TEI export of the VICAV Zotero Group library.
Private URIs using the dict prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a entry in the SHAWI glossary.

spanGrp.span: For the stuffed cabbage, when it's fresh, it's time to pickle it and put it in the jar. We take the cabbage, and let's say according to the household's needs, let's take 20 kilograms.
We take the 20 kilograms of cabbage and arrange them all, laying the leaves one on top of the other. The cabbage used is of the "ṣārma" type, meaning grape leaves.

We gather it during its season, as soon as the tree starts to sprout its leaves. It’s not done at any time; only when the tree begins to grow its branches and the leaves are still tender, we proceed with pickling it.

We gather all of it and lay it out horizontally, with the veins of the leaves stacked on top of each other. We sprinkle a little salt over them and continue layering them until it forms several layers. Then, we place it inside the jar.
We continue doing this until the jar is full. Then, we bring salt and water, mix them together, and add an egg. If the egg floats, it means the saltwater mixture is just right.
The salt concentration, if the egg floats, it floats like a metal piece. If the egg sinks to the bottom, it means the salt is still too little. It should be like seawater.

Yes, just like seawater can float a person due to its saltiness, when the egg floats, it indicates that the salt concentration is just right. When the egg floats, it means the salt level is perfect, and that's the correct measure for the brine.
We return to the grape leaves, to the jar. We fill the jar and place a stone or a lid on top. This is how we preserve the grape leaves for the winter.
To use it, whenever we want to make dinner, we open the jar and take some out, placing it in dishes a day before to remove the salt. Then, we wrap it and stuff it with rice.

Some people prefer to wrap it with bulgur (the kind used for food, not "çığ" bulgur), or with rice. So, we take the rice, add minced meat to it, let's say half a kilogram of "qiyyme" meat, and put it on.
We add tomato paste, red and black pepper, and garlic. We chop a head of garlic and an onion to add to it. We don’t put salt on it because it’s already pickled. If it’s pickled, we don’t add salt.
I’m afraid that if there’s still salt in the stuffed grape leaves, the food will become too salty. We also chop tomatoes and add them to the stuffing, then add water and mix everything together.
After mixing the stuffing, we open the grape leaves one by one and place a little bit of the stuffing inside each leaf. We then roll them up. This is what we call "Yabraq ṣarmasǝ."

We continue rolling until the pot is filled. If we want to add bones at the bottom to give a delicious flavor and prevent the food from sticking to the bottom, we place the bones and then arrange the grape leaves on top.
We continue until the jar is filled, but the quantity depends on the family size. Then, it is sealed with a stone. A clay stone is placed on top to prevent it from overflowing or spilling.
There is clay pottery here in the market. I will show you. It is placed inside the pot to hold and support, so it doesn’t rise up or cause the stuffed grape leaves (yabraq) to fall apart.

Then we return and add water, after it has been sealed with the stone. Not too much, just enough to cover the stone. After that, we close the pot and cook it. It takes about an hour, or an hour and a half, or even longer, depending on how well it needs to cook.
And when it's cooked, they call it "stuffed grape leaves," or "ṣarma." Ismail doesn't like it.
